The structure of hydrate is also of great importance in the field of materials science, as it is a promising material for high-pressure applications. However, the structure of hydrate at high pressure and low temperature has been a long-standing problem. In this work, we report the structure of hydrate at 480 MPa and 260 K. The structure is found to be the same as that at ambient pressure. This work provides a new insight into the structure of hydrate at high pressure and low temperature. The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of intense debate. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum mechanics. In this paper, we provide a categorical characterization of Hilbert space, which is the mathematical structure at the heart of quantum theory. Our characterization is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we report the genomes of two myxozoans, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare them to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to the more complex cnidarian group, the hydrozoa. In addition, we find that myxozoan genomes are among the smallest reported in animals and that they are highly reduced in gene content. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This represents a major transition in the evolution of parasites. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we describe a mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of the COVID-19 pandemic, is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the transcription factors. Our data reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune system and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the pandemic. (Show more)

However, the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. In this study, we show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the coming decades, and that this variability will increase even more if the global mean temperature continues to rise. This variability will increase the risk of food insecurity in many countries, especially in the developing world. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level plant consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that the proportion of grass consumption varied widely among species, from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the need for more comprehensive and accurate methods of quantifying diet composition. It also suggests that the coexistence of large herbivores may be more complex than previously thought.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Many small businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but they anticipate problems with accessing the program. We also assess the effects of loans relative to grants.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude and the fate of this pollution are still open questions. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show a worldwide distribution of plastic on the surface of the open ocean, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of each of the five subtropical gyres with comparable density. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of floating plastic debris, which points at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and intriguing questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the universe. In this study, we determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also found that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. These results provide evidence for an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The results also suggest that the solar system formed in a short time after the end of the dark ages. This is consistent with the idea that the solar system formed in a short time after the end of the dark ages. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most fundamental traits of life. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the most important factor is maternal metabolic power, which is the ability to convert food into energy. This is a surprising result, as it suggests that the most important factor in the evolution of mammals is not resource availability, but rather the ability to convert food into energy. This result has implications for the evolution of mammals and other organisms.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising drug for the treatment of MSA. This is the first study to show that a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy is able to limit α-syn accumulation in a mouse model of MSA. This study opens the door to the development of a drug that could be used to treat MSA. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling blood pressure, and regulating hemostasis. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is a network of cells that is responsible for integrating the multitude of signals that are received from the outside world. This paper describes the structure of the endothelium as a network of cells and the properties of the network that are important for the endothelium to function as a whole. The network is found to be small-world, which is a property that is not common in biological systems. This finding provides insight into the design of the endothelium and its ability to control the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of a data infrastructure that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 signals, including traditional public health surveillance data and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The infrastructure is open source and can be used by researchers and policy makers. We believe that this infrastructure will be useful to the research community and to public health decision-makers.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in potassium channels. This allosteric coupling is essential for the proper functioning of the channel. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this Threonine residue is essential for the proper functioning of the channel. We have also shown that this Threonine residue is essential for the proper functioning of the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a critical role in the health of the host. However, the potential for the microbiome to influence the health of the host is often overlooked. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, peptides, and polyketides. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This study highlights the potential of anaerobic fungi to be a source of natural products for the development of novel therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a potential explanation for the high prevalence of anxiety disorders in rats, which are the most commonly used animal model in neuroscience. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in the field of mechanical engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and structural patterns, which are often developed through trial and error. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures with arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The strategy is based on a digital model that is constructed by a free-form inverse design approach. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit irregular material distributions and complex shapes. The structures are then assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with desired behaviors for various applications.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. In humans, the hemoglobin system is regulated by the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), which is expressed in the fetal liver and is silenced in the adult bone marrow. Here we show that IGF2BP1 silencing in erythroid cells causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This phenotype is mediated by reduced expression of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is required for the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies and the use of fetal hemoglobin as a therapeutic. (show more)

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the transcriptional activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central regulator of lipid metabolism. Conversely, SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis. In preclinical models, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction resulted in near-complete tumor regression. These findings suggest that the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment in combination with ferroptosis induction. (show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Our study shows that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism that is distinct from that of other Ca2+ channel blockers. Our findings reveal a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular disease. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Instead, the policy failed to protect these species because of the continued loss of older forests due to fire and clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP is a unique case study for evaluating the effectiveness of a policy that is still in effect. Our findings highlight the need to continue to protect older forests and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks can be large, and the number of parameters can be a limiting factor in the size of the network and the number of parameters that can be trained. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is also easier to train and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-delay the circadian clock, and reduce sleep quality. These effects are likely to have important consequences for health, safety, and performance.

The Ytterby meteorite fell in Sweden in 1739 and provided the first evidence for the existence of extraterrestrial elements. The YDB is a chronostratigraphic marker used to identify the end of the last ice age and the onset of the penultimate interglacial period. The YDB is associated with a cooling of ∼6 °C and a change in the rate of sea level rise. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB is consistent with a terrestrial origin and that the spherules are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that an impact event triggered the YDB. (Show more)

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases is complex and depends on the stage of the disease. We found that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice resulted in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, our results suggest that CTLA-4 is a potential therapeutic target in autoimmune diseases. (Show more)

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that enable beetles to digest plant cell walls, and to trace the evolution of beetle species through time. We found that the evolution of these genes and beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and the adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable beetles to digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-SeekBar more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of cumulative cultural systems. This is an important contribution to the literature on the evolution of culture and the role of population size in the emergence of cumulative cultural systems.

APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is also associated with differential risk for AD. APOE isoforms are synthesized by astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE alleles are highly dependent on the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased risk for vascular dementia. These studies also provide a potential mechanism for the differential risk for AD associated with APO

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the Earth and the evolution of the core. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we propose a two-step nucleation mechanism of the inner core. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is the most stable phase of iron at high pressure and temperature. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase of iron from the bcc phase. This mechanism can explain the inner core nucleation paradox, which is a long-standing problem in geophysics. It also provides a new perspective for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. This study can be extended to other solid cores in the solar system. (show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well documented, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). The reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are key features of marijuana abuse. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use in the human brain.

We present a large-scale, integrative modeling study of the language comprehension system. We train deep learning models to predict neural and behavioral responses to sentences presented in fMRI and electrocorticography experiments. We find that these models can account for nearly all of the variation in the data, and that the models that best predict behavior also best predict neural activity. This suggests that predictive processing plays a fundamental role in the language comprehension system. We also find that model architecture is strongly associated with neural fit, suggesting that certain types of models are more likely to capture the key properties of the language comprehension system. These results provide computational evidence for the predictive coding framework in the language comprehension system and suggest that predictive processing may be a general principle of the system. Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific fields, but it is still an active area of research. One of the main challenges is that DL algorithms are often unstable, which means that they can produce results that are not only inaccurate but also completely wrong. We show that this instability is a consequence of the fact that the algorithms are not stable. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they are sufficient for the existence of stable algorithms. We also introduce a new class of neural networks that are stable and prove that they are sufficient for the existence of stable networks. This is a significant step forward in the development of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a prime example of the failure of social distancing. The failure is not due to a lack of knowledge about the virus or its transmission. Rather, it is due to a lack of social norms that would have prevented the spread of the virus. This paper discusses the failure of social norms in the context of a classic experiment that was published 45 years ago. The experiment is a classic example of a flawed experiment. Despite this, it is still cited as a prime example of how people fail to understand exponential growth.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and its history is intertwined with the development of modern medicine. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the leprosy bacillus, which has been the focus of intense study for the last century. We found that the leprosy bacilli have undergone extensive reductive evolution, and that the genomes of the two species are remarkably similar. This suggests that despite their ancient separation, the leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings have implications for the study of leprosy and its treatment. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental question in quantum physics. It is also a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics. However, the dynamics of entanglement in interacting systems is a long-standing challenge. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step forward in the study of the dynamics of entanglement in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. To control the pandemic, a large-scale vaccination program is needed. In this study, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is highly protective in a relevant hamster model. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate is also highly attenuated in hamsters, resulting in reduced lung pathology and weight loss. In addition, the vaccine candidate is stable at 4°C, which is a major advantage for large-scale manufacturing. These properties support the potential use of COVI-VAC in mass vaccination programs. Thus, COVI-VAC is a promising vaccine candidate for the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and death. It is also a disease that is still a threat to human health, as evidenced by the recent outbreaks in Central Asia. In this study, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neuroanatomy. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This study provides a more accurate picture of the evolution of brain neuronal density and its relationship with body size and brain size. It also provides a more accurate picture of the evolution of brain neuronal density and its relationship with brain size. This study has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The HSP90 chaperone family is a large and diverse group of proteins that are involved in a wide range of cellular processes. In cancer cells, HSP90 is a promising target for therapeutic intervention. However, the utility of HSP90 inhibitors as probes of HSP90 function in normal cells is questionable, because of the presence of HSP90-interacting proteins that are not found in normal cells. Here, we show that TRAP1, a member of the HSP90 family, is found predominantly in mitochondria and that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1 may therefore act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a rationale for the development of TRAP1-specific inhibitors as probes of TRAP1 function in normal and transformed cells. Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the main components of many signaling pathways. Actin filaments are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled by a family of proteins. These proteins are the focus of this study. We show that these proteins can sever actin filaments, and we show that the severing rate is enhanced when the filaments are held in a certain way. This mechanism is important for cells, because it allows them to control the dynamics of the cytoskeleton.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its relationship to the brain. They also suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. This may help explain why some people are more susceptible to the effects of fructose on appetite and weight gain. Understanding the mechanisms that underlie the effects of fructose on appetite and weight gain may lead to the development of new strategies for weight management. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The admixture happened recently, and the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar. It will be useful for the study of the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy population. It will also be useful for the study of the genomic diversity of the Indian Ocean islands. It will also be useful for the study of the genomic diversity of the African population.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work has implications for the design of social networks, as well as for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that can read mRNA sequences and translate the genetic code into proteins. The ribosome can also modify mRNA sequences, which can have a variety of effects on translation. In this work, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA (mRNA) codons can alter the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA codons and alter translation. Our work provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and more time spent in social activities and exercising. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or of outcome levels before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body size in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. The aquatic optimum size is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. These results provide a quantitative test of the energetic constraints on the evolution of body size in mammals and suggest that the evolution of larger body size is a consequence of the evolution of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is a major cause of lost work and school days, and the development of effective antiviral therapies is needed. Rhinoviruses are the leading cause of the common cold, and the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is a major obstacle to the development of antiviral therapies. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This temperature-dependent induction of antiviral defenses is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor MAVS and the type I IFN response. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication and suggest that targeting the type I IFN response may be a promising strategy for the development of antiviral therapies. Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces and regulate its virulence. This mechanism is based on the pili-mediated activation of the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like system that regulates the production of cAMP and the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The Chp system is activated by the mechanical activity of the pili, which are stretched by the action of the bacterial motor system. This study demonstrates that type IV pili can be used by bacteria as sensors for the mechanical activity of the cell surface. This is an important finding that could have implications for the development of new strategies for controlling bacterial infections. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture is a major cause of water pollution. However, the extent of pesticide contamination of surface water is not well understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global extent of pesticide contamination of surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillover from animals to humans. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a common North American cervid. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer, and that the virus has the potential to spread within deer populations. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to the development of effective strategies for mitigating the spread of the virus. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the impacts of dams, and the solutions that are needed. We propose that the industry needs to move away from building large dams and instead focus on smaller hydropower plants and other renewable energy sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of amyloid plaques. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still controversial. Here, we show that neurons are also vulnerable to Aβ and produce a variety of inflammatory factors, which correlate with the extent of microglial activation. We also demonstrate that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. These findings provide a novel perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they are precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are required for their cellular function. Np4 decapping is critical for the rapid degradation of those RNAs, which is necessary for the cell to adapt to stress. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping those transcripts in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress. Unexpectedly, RppH prefers to decape capped RNAs by attacking the δ-phosphate of the pyrophosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This unconventional mechanism for recognizing capped 5′ ends and the differential impact it has on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor prognosis. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine deprivation is a mechanism involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis. We also show that arginine deprivation is reversible by citrulline administration, which is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic strategy for sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We highlight that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to its original state in a time that is proportional to the power of the system size. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including sandpiles, earthquakes, and neural networks. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering, and that the bandgap can be tuned continuously. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of novel strategies for the control of plant fungal diseases. Here, we report the discovery of a novel antifungal peptide, NCR044, from the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. The structure of the peptide was solved by NMR spectroscopy, and it was found to be highly dynamic and largely disordered. The peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and it was able to penetrate the fungal cell wall and membrane. The peptide also bound to phosphoinositides, which are important components of the fungal cell wall. The antifungal activity of the peptide was demonstrated in planta. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the peptide, and it paves the way for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This would be a significant advance in the control of plant fungal diseases. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract provides a reservoir of proteins that support the viability of sperm during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of Drosophila sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD mutations. The mechanism also explains the effects of VWD mutations on the binding of VWF to platelets, and the effects of VWD mutations on the bleeding and clotting of patients with VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. The database is based on a large number of publicly available metagenomic datasets, which were analyzed to identify viral sequences. The database contains information on the location of the viral sequences in the genome, as well as information on the taxonomy of the viruses. The database can be used to study the diversity of viruses in the microbiome, as well as to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI process is difficult to be observed. This study introduces a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. The dual-FOV HSRL is used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This study provides a new way to observe ACI. It is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI research.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth, as well as for understanding the history of the planet itself. In this paper, we use the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to determine the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are classified into three types based on their gating mechanism: voltage-gated, ligand-gated, and calcium-gated. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is the most abundant K+ channel in the heart and is the main target of the antiarrhythmic drug quinidine. We found that the BK channel’s gating mechanism is different from that of other K+ channels. We also found that the BK channel’s gating mechanism is similar to that of the Shaker channel. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This finding may help us understand the mechanism of the BK channel’s drug sensitivity and the development of new drugs. (show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with the parasite invading the red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The malaria parasite exploits a variety of mechanisms to facilitate invasion, including the binding of its erythrocyte-binding antigen to the host cell receptor. Here, we show that the binding of the malaria parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 to the host cell receptor leads to a change in the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This study provides a major change in our understanding of the malaria invasion process, suggesting that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This finding could lead to the development of new strategies for the control of malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of low ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. This may be particularly important in the context of

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a tree-like fashion, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence is organized in a way that is consistent with a tree-like structure. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to combine words into phrases, and that this operation is applied equally to words in a sentence and to words in a word list. This merge operation is consistent with a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our findings provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation and suggest that the brain uses this operation to build syntactic structures. This may be a fundamental process in language comprehension.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway in development and homeostasis. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its function is to convert signals at the plasma membrane to signals that inhibit the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

Obesity is a major public health problem, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are not fully understood. Here we describe a circuit in the brain that may contribute to overeating. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. This circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, but not in dopamine neurons in the nucleus accumbens. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and their bacteria would be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for controlling the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to deliver biologically fixed nitrogen to cereal crops, which would be expected to increase crop productivity and nitrogen use efficiency. It could also be used to deliver nitrogen to other crops, such as oilseed rape, which are not suitable for N2-fixing symbiosis. This work also represents a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine, a bacterial signal, as a synthetic plant-controlled signal.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation, but the alerts are often generated too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense for all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. However, the diversity of the auditory organs of these animals is astonishing, and they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its proteinaceous, self-manufactured web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We show that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C of warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. This would be a major step toward a sustainable future.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) lack access to these vaccines. We report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. We also report the design and synthesis of a virus-like particle (VLP) that presents the variant RBD. This VLP can be produced in large quantities, and the VLP-based vaccine provides protection in hamsters. These results suggest that this variant RBD and the VLP-based vaccine can be used to develop a global vaccine strategy for LMICs. This strategy would provide a cost-effective, large-volume vaccine that can be produced in many countries. Such a strategy would be a significant step forward in the global response to the pandemic. (Show more)

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is a family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a variety of biological processes. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs (DrALKs) are activated by secreted ligands. We demonstrate that the secreted ligands are members of the ALKAL family, which are expressed in the neural crest. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. This study provides a link between the ALK family of RTKs and the neural crest. This knowledge will be useful for understanding the role of ALK family receptors in development and disease. (Show more)

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-established hypothesis. However, the timing and geographic spread of this event are still debated. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical time period for understanding the spread of plague. Our results suggest that the plague lineage was already widespread across Eurasia, with a rapid expansion over the course of a few centuries. This study provides new insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to massive emissions of carbon (C) to the atmosphere. This has been driven by the widespread adoption of intensive crop production on grassland-derived Mollisols. We show that soil health management practices can mitigate this trend. We also show that the effects of these practices on soil C dynamics are highly dependent on the crop rotation and livestock integration. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester C and provide a framework for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems. This is an important step forward in the development of a holistic approach to soil health and climate change mitigation.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the drivers of zoonotic spillover and spread of novel viruses in humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify the host, viral, and environmental risk factors associated with spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying the evolution of nectar color are not well understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We identify the three enzymatic activities that are necessary for the production of this pigment, and we show that the same enzymatic activities are responsible for the evolution of the red nectar of two other plants, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of this important plant trait. It also suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography, but the processes that shaped this structure are not fully understood. We present a case study of a group of individuals from southern Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of these individuals is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia, and includes a group of women with artificial skull deformations. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results provide insights into the processes that shaped the genetic structure of modern Europeans. They also indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. These findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future outbreaks of MERS-CoV and other bat coronav

The ability to rapidly identify the pathogen responsible for an undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for the early deployment of public health response. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to sequence the pathogen RNA of 489 febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the potential of pathogen-agnostic metagenomic sequencing to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the pathogen landscape and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied in other resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate the impact of emerging pathogens. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. The lagging strand template is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a processive manner, but the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic assays that provide a detailed picture of the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We show that the pol δ holoenzyme is not stable and dissociates rapidly. This behavior is important for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA at a DNA lesion. These results provide a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to have catalytic activity, but the evolution of catalytic RNA that can replicate itself is a formidable challenge. Here, we report the successful evolution of a catalytic RNA polymerase that can replicate itself. This polymerase can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA, and can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold. Thus, the polymerase can serve as a building block for the construction of an RNA-based cell. This work provides a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting interleukin 6, can significantly improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. This study provides a new treatment strategy for COVID-19. It is expected to be a reference for the treatment of COVID-19 in the future.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also a highly toxic metal that can cause severe damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-containing metabolites suggests a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a previously unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides a framework for the study of the role of fungal natural products in metal homeostasis and the control of interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

The formation of silica-rich minerals in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The sedimentary environment at the time of tridymite formation is also rare on Earth. The diagenesis of the silica-rich sediment at the time of formation is also unique.
